newsitem.title: POLAND: SAB, POLISH FIRM BUY TYCHY BREWER.
newsitem.headline: SAB, POLISH FIRM BUY TYCHY BREWER.

text.p: A company formed by the South African Breweries Ltd (SAB) and Poland's Euro Agro Centrum SA bought late on Monday a 52 percent stake in the Polish Tychy brewery for $75 million, the privatisation ministry said.
It said in a statement that under the agreement the company, Kompania Piwna SA, pledged to invest a further $75 million in Tychy, but planned to invest at least $115 million over the next five years.
The funds would be spent on boosting Tychy's production potential, improving its distribution network and marketing.
Kampania Piwna SA wants to invest $26 million in Tychy within the next 12 months, the statement said.
The firm agreed to keep Tychy's jobs for four years and raise wages.

Tychy's employees will receive 15 percent of shares, five percent will be retained by the treasury for reprivatisation claims and further 28 percent will be set aside for yet-to-be created pension funds.

South African Breweries Ltd have a one third stake in Kompania Piwna SA while Euro Agro Centrum has two thirds of votes. However, SAB controlls 27.5 percent in Euro Agro centrum through its stake in a Dutch-based firm Kulczyk Investment B.V.
Euro Agro centrum also has a majority stake in another Polish brewery Lech Browary Wielkopolski SA.

Tychy, Poland's second largest brewery, sold 1.417 million hectolitres of beer in the first nine months of this year and its board expects sales would rise to 1.75 million hectolitres this year from 1.6 million hectolitres in 1995.
It expects to net 42 million zlotys this year against 23.6 million zlotys in 1995.
